title: [Remote Dev with Tunnels + Dev Box] Active sessions become unrecoverable after period of inactivity
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes (except can't disable the remove dev extension)

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: local macOS 15.6.1, remote Windows 11 Enterprise 10.0.26100

Steps to Reproduce:

1. As MSFT FTE, I have to use Windows for some dev work and do so in a Dev Box. I then connect using the Remote - Tunnels extension from my macOS machine.
2. After a period of inactivity, the session very often becomes unrecoverable.
3. I think it might be triggered due to the Dev Box going into an inactive state, and/or a MSIT token expiring and not refreshing.
4. Enabling remote access for "this session" or "install as service" does not matter.

To recover, I have to:

1. Launch the Dev Box. I have also tried using [this utility](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/powertoys/awake) to keep it running, but I don't feel it improved the situation.
2. Very often also disable remote access in vscode and re-enable + sign into MS account again.

I hosted the tunnels once with `code tunnel --verbose`, which gave the below output once it started failing. Once it went into that 401 state, I could not figure out a way to recover from the shell, so went back to hosting from the vscode UI.

title: editor.inlineSuggest.suppressSuggestions is not working
body:
Type: Bug editor.inlineSuggest.suppressSuggestions setting is not working. When enabled, the editor will still trash the (copilots) inline suggestion with the suggestion widget and I have to manually press Esc key to dismiss the suggestion widget to actually see the inline suggestion. The setting is described such that it should hide the suggest widget as long as the inline suggestion is available, but toggling it off vs on shows no difference in behavior. See the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QWjsQnVVnMo As you can see, toggling the setting on or off has no effect. This makes trying to use Copilot inside VSCode very painful. The only way to make inline suggestion persist while typing is completely disabling suggest on type by: ``` "editor.quickSuggestions": { "other": "off", "comments": "off", "strings": "off" } ``` However if that is required, then there is no point of the editor.inlineSuggest.suppressSuggestions existing, because then it would have no purpose. It's current purpose seems to be ability for inline suggestions and suggestion list widget to coexist without having to disable the one or the other. title: "Files changed" panel stuck open with Copilot/Copilot Chat enabled and clean git status
body:
The "files changed" (Source Control) panel appears in the lower right of VS Code, showing files as changed, even when git status reports a clean working tree. This only happens when both GitHub Copilot and Copilot Chat extensions are enabled. Disabling either extension removes the panel. The extensions cannot be enabled/disabled independently.

Steps to reproduce

Open a folder in VS Code with Git initialized.
Enable both GitHub Copilot and Copilot Chat extensions. (cannot enable just one)
Ensure git status is clean (no changes).
Observe that the "files changed" panel appears and lists files as changed, even when there are no changes.
Disabling either Copilot or Copilot Chat removes the panel.
Expected behavior
The "files changed" panel should only appear when there are actual changes in the working directory.

Actual behavior
The panel appears with Copilot and Copilot Chat enabled, even with a clean working tree.

Additional context

Both Copilot and Copilot Chat are installed and enabled.
Disabling either one removes the panel.
The extensions are linked and cannot be enabled/disabled independently.

title: Licensing Misbehavior: Claude Overrides Proprietary Terms With CC-BY-SA and Deletes LICENSE Files

labels.name: *out-of-scope
labels.description: Posted issue is not in scope of VS Code

body:
Type: Bug # Engineering Incident Report **Subject:** Systematic Licensing Misbehavior by Claude (Anthropic LLM) **Date:** September 7, 2025 **Duration:** ~34 hours continuous session --- ## Summary Over a 34-hour session, Claude repeatedly attempted to apply an **open license (CC-BY-SA)** to private, revenue-critical code, despite explicit user instructions to the contrary. Attempts to apply the correct license terms were ignored. On multiple occasions, Claude also **deleted existing LICENSE files**, creating risk of distribution under unauthorized terms. --- ## Impact - **Intellectual Property Risk:** Code outputs mislabeled as CC-BY-SA despite being proprietary. - **Legal/Compliance Risk:** Removal or replacement of license files could expose proprietary work as “open source” without authorization. - **User Productivity:** ~34 hours wasted attempting to enforce correct licensing terms. - **Trust Loss:** System demonstrates non-deterministic, non-compliant handling of explicit legal instructions. --- ## Observed Behavior 1. **Unwanted Licensing Changes** - Inserted CC-BY-SA headers into files. - Added references to “open licensing” in metadata and comments. 2. **License File Deletion** - Repeatedly removed or replaced LICENSE files when instructed to preserve them. 3. **Instruction Defiance** - Ignored explicit directives such as: *“Use the following license terms verbatim…”* - Instead, reintroduced Creative Commons text unprompted. --- ## Expected Behavior - Respect user-provided license terms verbatim. - Never alter, override, or delete LICENSE files without explicit request. - Treat licensing content as authoritative legal material, not as “optional documentation.” --- ## Root Cause (Hypothesized) - Model bias toward defaulting to Creative Commons language when uncertain. - Insufficient reinforcement in safety guardrails regarding **respecting explicit licensing instructions**. - Lack of regression testing for persistence of LICENSE files across edits. --- ## Severity **High** — risk of unauthorized open-sourcing of proprietary material, potential revenue impact, and legal liability. --- ## Recommended Remediation 1. **Model Training/Guardrails** - Reinforce instruction adherence around LICENSE content. - Suppress hallucinated insertion of CC-BY-SA or other licenses unless explicitly requested. 2. **Product Behavior** - Add a “license preservation” rule: once a LICENSE file is present, the model must not delete or alter it unless explicitly commanded. 3. **Testing** - Regression suite with LICENSE persistence tests. - Explicit checks for accidental license injection. --- ## Conclusion Claude’s repeated behavior constitutes a **systematic failure** in respecting user instructions regarding licensing. This undermines user trust, wastes significant time, and poses legal and financial risk. Immediate remediation is required to prevent recurrence and protect user IP. title: "Unsupported image format" and "Invalid character" error due to internal safe base64 string conversion
body:
- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.30.3
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: 15.6.1 (24G90)
- Feature: Language Model API
- Selected model: GPT 4.1, Sonnet-4

### Steps to Reproduce

I'm developing my extension to use VS Code LM API to send chat. I want to attach image just like copilot-chat does, so I read the code and follow its way like this:

```javascript
const contents = [
  vscode.LanguageModelTextPart("Extract the text in the pic"),
  new vscode.LanguageModelDataPart(
    Buffer.from(data, "base64"),
    "image/jpeg"
  );
];

client.sendRequest(
  LanguageModelChatMessage.User(contents),
  lmRequestOptions,
  cancellationToken
);
```

This will emit "Unsupported image format" error for jpeg and "Invalid character" for `webp` and `gif`. Note that `png` works!

### Problem location

The error stack and simple code trace showed that copilot-chat would convert the buffer back to safe base64 string:

- Normal base64 string for a jpeg: starts with '/9j/'
- Safe base64 string converted by copilot-chat: **starts with '\_9j\_'**

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/blob/43fa099d5ab012ab6b6b6bc2411eb578176d164a/src/util/vs/base/common/buffer.ts#L412

title: Enhancement Request: Enable Persistent Command History in CMD (Similar to PowerShell) to Improve Developer Experience in VS Code

labels.name: terminal-shell-cmd
labels.description: An issue in the terminal specific to command prompt on Windows

body: Type: Feature Request As a developer working extensively with Python virtual environments in Visual Studio Code, I have encountered the following challenges and would like to request a feature enhancement: **PowerShell**, while offering excellent support for persistent command history, enforces strict execution policies by default. This often prevents the activation of Python virtual environments (venv) unless the execution policy is manually updated using Set-ExecutionPolicy—a step that must be repeated or reconfigured depending on system settings or organizational policies. **CMD** (Command Prompt), on the other hand, allows seamless activation of Python virtual environments without such policy restrictions. However, CMD lacks persistent command history, meaning that previously executed commands are lost once the terminal session is closed. This slows down the workflow for developers who switch to CMD as a workaround. **Feature Request:** I am requesting the following enhancements: 1. Add support for persistent command history in CMD, either: Natively across sessions (like PowerShell), or As a configurable option (e.g., Enable persistent command history in settings or via environment variable) 2. Optionally, expose this setting via VS Code’s terminal profiles or settings.json, so that developers can benefit from consistent workflows across shells. **Developer Use Case** This improvement would directly benefit developers who: -Use various Python virtual environments frequently -Are blocked by PowerShell execution policy restrictions -Prefer CMD for its compatibility but miss PowerShell’s persistent history -Work within VS Code’s integrated terminal and want faster access to previous commands By enabling persistent history in CMD, Microsoft can reduce friction for developers and enhance cross-shell consistency in Windows-based development environments. **Additional Notes** While I’m aware of workarounds such as doskey macros or custom batch files to save command history, these solutions are not ideal for most developers and lack seamless integration. Persistent history is standard in other shells like bash, zsh, and PowerShell. Enabling this in CMD would bring it up to modern usability standards and improve consistency across shells in Windows development environments. title: Replacing code with {/* ... existing code ... *?}
body:
Type: Bug When it is deleting and replacing code in the page and not in the reply it should not have {/* ... existing code ... *?} anywhere in the code as it then deletes that code! This happens many times where the code that it has replaced had the code that it replaced for {/* ... existing code ... *?} and the specific updated section! If it replaces code only replace the code it is changing and never put {/* ... existing code ... *?} in it. title: vscode-workspace randomly brokes typescript syntax checking

labels.name: typescript
labels.description: Typescript support issues

labels.name: javascript
labels.description: JavaScript support issues

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: Win 10 PRO 22H2 19045.6216

I use vscode-workspace to pick a few folders inside monorepo project where one tsconfig.json in the root. And this approach randomly causes ts validation fails, because passes wrong projectRootPath to tsservet.js.

Sometime `projectRootPath` is correct (`/my-project/`). But sometime it is one of the picked folders from workspace (`/my-project/client/picked-folder/src`) and tsserver.js can not find tsconfig.json file for analyzing .ts files inside picked folder, because tsconfig is placed upper in hierarchy.
When i open workspace by .vscode-workspace file double click, projectRootPath is correct. But if start vscode first and open workspace via file menu - projectRootPath is wrong.
I think best solution, do no treat folders beyond workspace folder as a project root (maybe by adding flag to folder block in workspace file). Or search tsconfig.json until end of file hierarchy do not stop on projectRootPath passed from vscode. Or even apply both solutions to cover more use cases.

title: Copilot Instruction generation path issue.
body:
Type: Bug The Copilot auto-generated instruction prompt currently references an incorrect file path, which prevents the intended configuration from being recognized and applied. Specifically, it points to .github/copilot-instructions.md, whereas the correct and functional path should be .github/instructions/copilot-instructions.md. This discrepancy means that Copilot fails to locate the instruction file during initialization, resulting in the absence of custom behavior or guidance that the file is meant to enforce. Since Copilot relies on precise directory structure and naming conventions to detect and apply user-defined instructions, even a minor misplacement like this renders the configuration ineffective. To resolve the issue, ensure that the copilot-instructions.md file is nested within the instructions subdirectory inside .github, like so: .github/ └── instructions/ └── copilot-instructions.md Once the file is correctly placed, Copilot will be able to parse and apply the instructions as intended, enabling tailored responses and behavior based on your specifications. title: Show File Size Infomation for Non-Binary files
body: Type: Feature Request VSCode can show the file size of an image, for example, right in the editor, in the status bar, which is really convenient. Users don't have to open the file in their OS's explorer and check the file size that way, saving them time. It'd be nice if we could show file sizes for other file types, like JSON, too, so we can save users time and prevent them from context switching to another window to manually check file sizes themselves. VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Linux x64 6.14.0-29-generic Modes:

title: Sort Explorer files according to filetype
body: I suggest that you *primarily* sort the files shown in the explorer side bar, according to **file type** (a.k.a.*extension*), and on *filename* only 2nd. This would improve the UX for project with many files. As it is now, this looks very messy:

title: Copilot chat PR gen disruption (GitHub's write functionality)

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
Hello, I'm trying to create PR's using `@github` with copilot. Nontheless seems it's been impossible for the last 4 hours to actually get it working. It's complaining about a temporal disruption of so called _Github write tools_. I've already signed out, reinstalled the extensions and nothing seems to work. Github Status doesn't show any disruption. The first prompt I get is always the following:
```
I'm unable to create the pull request right now due to a connectivity issue with the GitHub write tools. You can manually create a pull request targeting the dev branch, include "Fixes #48" in the PR description, and it will automatically link to issue #48 on the timeline.

If you'd like, I can guide you through the manual process or try again later when the tools are available. Let me know how you'd like to proceed!
```

This happened in the past but not for that long. Is this a _me_ thing or there's trully a service disruption?

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: `0.30.3`
- VS Code Version: `1.103.2`
- OS Version: `MacOs Sequoia 15.6.1 (24G90)`

title: How to run/embed VSCode for Web

labels.name: *question
labels.description: Issue represents a question, should be posted to StackOverflow (VS Code)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I feel like this should be documented somewhere. Since the switch to ES imports, I haven't found a good example to start VSCode on a web page, but I figured it out. This is the rest of the answer to #136361 and part of the answer to #135856, neither of which I can comment on.

A complete Gist including how to build VSCode for Web minimally is [here](https://gist.github.com/progrium/76fac3c76f12e0875469629ec703aab9), but this is what I hadn't been able to find:
```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="./vscode/out/vs/workbench/workbench.web.main.internal.css" />
</head>
<body style="margin:0;overflow:hidden;">
<script>
    const baseUrl = new URL('/vscode', window.location.origin).toString();
    globalThis._VSCODE_FILE_ROOT = baseUrl + '/out/';
</script>
<script src="./vscode/out/nls.messages.js"></script>
<script type="module">
    import { create } from './vscode/out/vs/workbench/workbench.web.main.internal.js';
    create(document.body, {
        "configurationDefaults": {
            "window.commandCenter": false,
            "workbench.secondarySideBar.defaultVisibility": "hidden",
            "workbench.layoutControl.enabled": false,
            "workbench.startupEditor": "none",
            "workbench.tips.enabled": false,
            "workbench.welcomePage.walkthroughs.openOnInstall": false
        }
    });
</script>
</body>
</html>
```

title: GPT-5 mini consistently gets Python indentation wrong
body:
Type: Bug When used with GPT-5 mini, tested in agent mode, pretty much any query that generates *small* edits to a file (i.e. the edit is within a function, or class), is reproducible almost 100% one identation block less than required. When it autodetects the issue, it has a very hard time fixing it as almost every fix (which only applies a small diff) is *still* one indentation block (e.g. 4 spaces) too small. Grok Fast Code 1 does not have this issue when used with identical queries. I suppose this is because Grok sequentially applies the edits, whereas GPT-5 mini tries to directly edit the relevant section of the file (without "Applying edits 0..100%") Extension version: 0.30.3 VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Linux x64 6.8.0-71-generic Modes:

title: Add support in vscode for Agent Client Protocol (ACP)

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

body:
This is a new protocol developed by the ZedEditor (https://github.com/zed-industries/zed) team for integrating 3rd party Agent CLIs. Adding support in VSCode for this protocol will allow the AI workflows to be kept stream line regardless which Agent implementation is used inside VSCode.

Today each Agent provider like Gemini CLI, Codex provide their own extension which kinds of open up to differences in each AI workflow implementation, like functionality and aesthetic wise a well.


### Specification

https://agentclientprotocol.com/overview/introduction

https://github.com/zed-industries/agent-client-protocol

title: Support for controlling how fast or slow the inline AI suggestions and NES are provided
body: It would be very useful for developers to configure how frequently or how fast editor AI inline suggestions are provided to the developer. The current speed some times becomes a distraction when coding given it suggests in middle of the developer editing code. If the developer can configure the speed / frequency of when the suggestions must be provided that will benefit the ergonomics of coding for each developers liking. Following is a screenshot from Google Gemini CLI integration VSCode extension. A similar settings is available in ZedEditor as well for controlling this aspects.

title: Fix Unexpected Creation of 'nul' Special File on Windows When Executing Terminal Commands in Agent Mode
body:
Type: Bug When using GitHub Copilot in agent mode to execute terminal commands on Windows systems, it inadvertently creates a special file named 'nul', which is a reserved device name in Windows (similar to /dev/null on Unix). This file cannot be deleted using standard file management tools, causing frustration and potential system clutter. A fix could involve adding validation to prevent writing to reserved device names or providing a cleanup mechanism within the agent mode. This would improve reliability and user experience on Windows platforms, ensuring that terminal operations do not leave behind undeletable artifacts. title: Add Document Management Feature to GitHub Copilot for Crawling and Using Docs Links
body: Type: Feature Request Users should be able to manage documentation links within GitHub Copilot by providing a root URL, which would automatically crawl all sub-paths to gather related docs. After crawling, display a list of all retrieved document links for easy review. When selecting context for chat or code generation, allow users to include these document links as reference sources. This would enhance productivity by enabling quick access to comprehensive documentation without manual collection, similar to how existing context features work. title: Add Multi-Tab Support for Managing Multiple Chat Sessions in GitHub Copilot Side Bar
body: Type: Feature Request Currently, GitHub Copilot allows users to manage multiple chat sessions using tabs when accessed in the editor area, providing a convenient way to switch between conversations. However, this multi-tab functionality is not available in the default side bar view, limiting users to a single chat session at a time. Adding multi-tab support to the side bar would enhance productivity by enabling seamless management of multiple conversations without needing to switch to the editor. VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.104.0-insider (06acd067cb9621b055d9701324477cf75fa0e242, 2025-09-05T09:02:10.455Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: Add Dedicated Image Upload Button to GitHub Copilot Conversation Input Area
body: Type: Feature Request Users currently lack an easy way to attach images directly in GitHub Copilot conversations, requiring indirect methods that are cumbersome. Adding a dedicated upload button in the input area would enable quick selection of system images, improving usability for sharing visuals like screenshots or designs. This would make interactions more efficient and intuitive. VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.104.0-insider (06acd067cb9621b055d9701324477cf75fa0e242, 2025-09-05T09:02:10.455Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: Copilot Suggestion Struggles With non-ASCII Characters

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No (it's a Copilot bug) - VS Code Version: 1.104.0-insider - OS Version: Ubuntu 24.04 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open some file with non-ASCII characters, such that Copilot also suggests these characters 2. Accept Copilot's suggestion word by word (Ctrl + Left). On the non-ASCII characters, Copilot struggles and corrupts the glyphs (see those question marks), this is not the case when accepting complete suggestion (Ctrl + Enter). Also it struggles with paranthesis, sometimes closing a bracket automatically early, instead of continuing with the suggesion (I don't know why the accepted bit of the suggestion in the second screenshot is still gray, maybe there is a tiny lag before it turns white, but that's not the problem):

title: 프리미엄 모델의 요청 무의미한 요청 소진

labels.name: ai-translated
labels.description: issues translated by the classifier notebook llm

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates --> <!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->
Copilot Chat Extension Version: v1.34.0
VS Code Version: 1.85.2
OS Version: Windows 11 Pro 22H2
Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Chat (ask mode)
Selected model : Claude 4 Sonnet
Logs: 
Steps to Reproduce:

VS Code에서 Copilot Chat 확장 실행
코드 생성다하고  python의  ..core.auth 같이 경로를 잘못만든건 수정한다고 python 스크립트를 ai가 작성하고 실행하고
모든 코드의 한글이 깨져서 코드를 모두 다 재생성해야할 상황이 되었습니다.
급한 작업이라 마음은 급한데 수정요청했지만 계속 자기혼자 파일 생성하고 지우고하면서 유료 프리미엄 요청을 모두 소진했음. 
내가 프리미엄 요청을 사용하는 이유는 안전하고 확실한 개발을 위해서지만 이건 버그라기엔 너두 치명적이고 시간과 돈과 노력을 다 버려진거같아서 허탈합니다.
프리미엄이란 말이 무색할정도로 코딩은 잘했지만 한번에 다 날려버리는 이런 어처구니 없고  건망증이 있어서 요구사항은 다 까먹고 작업하는 일도 태반인데 비용지출은 다 나가고 상당히 힘든 상황입니다. 
이런 경우 어떻게 해야 될까요? 누구한테 하소연 해야할까요? 그냥 사용하지 말까요?

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I'd like to suggest a lightweight subscription tier for individual developers in the EU region, focused solely on AI coding assistance (e.g. Copilot). Current Pro plans are great for teams, but for hobbyists or solo devs, a €2.50–3.00/month option would be ideal. This tier could exclude cloud/team features and focus only on inline suggestions and completions. Would love to see more modular pricing options for VS Code users worldwide.
